introduction.title: How Cloud Computing Works
introduction.description: This short, interactive activity will guide you through the methods and techniques of the cloud, from its foundations to its deployment.
introduction.part1Desc: Tackle 'Myth vs. Fact' questions about what the cloud really is.
introduction.part2Desc: Play a drag-and-drop game to sort IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS.
introduction.part3Desc: Solve real-world scenarios to understand Public, Private, and Hybrid clouds.

part1.title: Part 1: The Foundation
part1.subtitle: Is the following statement a myth or a fact?

questions.q1_statement: The foundations of cloud computing are high-powered computers called servers, located in facilities called data centers.
questions.q1_explanation: That's right! The cloud's central innovation is placing large numbers of servers in data centers, typically located far from the individuals and organizations that access them.
questions.q2_statement: Cloud computing requires organizations to buy and operate their own computer equipment on-premises.
questions.q2_explanation: Exactly. Historically, organizations operated their own on-premises equipment. Cloud computing allows them to access resources remotely from a cloud provider instead.

part2.title: Part 2: Service Models
part2.subtitle: Drag each example to the correct service model category.

examples.ex1_text: Paying for storage space that automatically scales to match the amount of data in use.
examples.ex1_explanation: You got it. Scalable storage is a core component of infrastructure that you rent from a provider. This is a classic IaaS offering.
examples.ex1_hint_paas: While a PaaS application would *use* storage, the storage service itself is a more fundamental building block. It's part of the core infrastructure.
examples.ex1_hint_saas: This isn't a complete application, but a raw component you'd use to build one. Which model provides these fundamental building blocks?
examples.ex2_text: Using Zoom for video calls or Slack for messaging.
examples.ex2_explanation: That's it! These are examples of complete software products that you access, typically by paying a subscription. This is Software as a Service.
examples.ex2_hint_iaas: With Zoom or Slack, are you managing servers or just using an app? IaaS is about renting the servers themselves. This is a level above that.
examples.ex2_hint_paas: PaaS is a platform for developers to *create* apps. Zoom is an app that has already been created for you to use. Which model fits that description?
examples.ex3_text: Operating your own software in the cloud while a provider handles and maintains the servers.
examples.ex3_explanation: Perfect! With PaaS, you focus on your application code, while the provider handles the underlying infrastructure and technical responsibilities, like server maintenance.
examples.ex3_hint_iaas: You're getting warmer! IaaS would give you the server, but you would be responsible for maintaining it. This service handles that maintenance for you.
examples.ex3_hint_saas: This is a model for *running* your own software, not for *using* someone else's. Which category provides that kind of platform?
examples.ex4_text: Accessing a file sharing service to collaborate with a team.
examples.ex4_explanation: Correct! A file sharing service is a ready-to-use application provided for end-users, which is the definition of SaaS.
examples.ex4_hint_iaas: File sharing is a feature of a complete software product. IaaS would be renting the raw storage where those files are kept.
examples.ex4_hint_paas: You are *using* a finished service, not *building* one. PaaS is the environment for building. What's the model for using?
examples.ex5_text: Using a provider's infrastructure for large-scale data processing and analytics.
examples.ex5_explanation: Exactly! You are renting the provider's fundamental computing resources (their infrastructure) to perform complex tasks. This is IaaS.
examples.ex5_hint_paas: PaaS provides a managed platform, but when you're directly utilizing raw processing power and storage for custom analytics, you're using the underlying infrastructure.
examples.ex5_hint_saas: This describes using core computing power, not a specific, pre-built software application. Which model is about renting raw resources?
examples.ex6_text: Hosting your company's custom application and its business analytics tools.
examples.ex6_explanation: That's right. When you deploy and run your own software and tools on a managed environment from a cloud provider, that's Platform as a Service.
examples.ex6_hint_iaas: You could do this with IaaS, but you'd also have to manage the operating systems and servers. PaaS handles that for you so you can focus on your app.
examples.ex6_hint_saas: This is about running your *own* custom application, not subscribing to one made by someone else. Which model provides a platform for your own software?
examples.default_hint: That doesn't seem to be the right fit. Think about the level of management provided by the service.

part3.title: Part 3: Deployment Models
part3.subtitle: Read the scenario and choose the most appropriate cloud model.

scenarios.q1_scenario: A financial firm needs to store proprietary research with greater security, requiring an encrypted VPN connection for its employees to access it.
scenarios.q1_explanation: A Private Cloud is ideal here. It offers the greatest security by imposing more restrictions on access, making it suitable for sensitive information like financial records or proprietary research.
scenarios.q2_scenario: A software company wants to deploy its app for nearly any customer to use, with easy access over standard internet connections and lower costs.
scenarios.q2_explanation: A Public Cloud is the perfect choice. They are called 'public' because nearly any customer can pay to use their servers, making them cheaper and offering easy access.
scenarios.q3_scenario: A company runs its videoconferencing software on a public cloud but stores its sensitive customer service records in a separate, more secure environment.
scenarios.q3_explanation: This is a classic Hybrid Cloud. This model involves splitting data and applications across public and private clouds to combine the benefits of both.
scenarios.default_explanation: That's a good thought, but there's a better fit. Consider the key requirements of the scenario.

summary.title: Great Job!
summary.description: You've completed the introduction to how cloud computing works. Here's a quick recap of what you learned.
summary.recapFoundationsDesc: The cloud is a physical network of servers in data centers, accessed remotely.
summary.recapIaaS: is renting a provider's cloud infrastructure (servers, storage).
summary.recapPaaS: is a platform to operate your own software on, where the provider handles the servers.
summary.recapSaaS: is paying to access another organization's ready-to-use software.
summary.recapPublic: is shared, cost-effective, and easily accessible.
summary.recapPrivate: is dedicated to a single customer for greater security and control.
summary.recapHybrid: combines public and private clouds for flexibility.
